docs.lead_paragraph: ''I'm a crazy old woman,'' Edna Adan Ismail said only a minute or two after introducing herself. ''You might as well know that from the start.'' If that must be one's fate, one might as well do it as Ms. Ismail has. She looks wonderful, to begin with -- a queenly woman of 62, beautiful in her gold Ghanaian gown and head wrap.

headline.main: Hargeisa Journal; A Woman of Firsts and Her Latest Feat: A Hospital

docs.abstract: Enda Adnan Ismail, former first lady of Somalia and a public health expert, has poured $300,000 of personal savings into construction of maternity hospital for poor women in city of Hargeisa, capital of self-proclaimed Republic of Somaliland; she says money is running out and finishing hospital is turning out to be difficult; map; photo (M)
docs.snippet: ''I'm a crazy old woman,'' Edna Adan Ismail said only a minute or two after introducing herself. ''You might as well know that from the start.''    If that must be one's fate, one might as well do it as Ms. Ismail has. She looks wonderful, to begin...

docs.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Alexander was sitting comfortably in his stroller, ready to roll. His twin sister, Rachel, was screaming. She did not want to wear a jacket. She did not want to take a walk. She did not want to do much of anything, it seemed, but arch her back and wail in protest. Suddenly, as if in sympathy, Jonathan joined her. Their mother, Robin Pollock, quickly attached Rachel to a baby carrier on her chest, while a baby sitter on standby stuck a pacifier in the little girl's mouth. One 13-month-old twin in the stroller, one attached to her mother's chest, out of their apartment and into the elevator they went. Making their way through the lobby was akin to a final maneuver in a playoff game: a quick move to the left, a fast pull to the right -- 22 minutes from the front door to the street. It was almost time for lunch.

headline.main: More Traffic in the Double-Stroller Lane; Twin Births Surge, and the Parents Face Special, and Costly, Challenges

docs.abstract: Article discusses surge in birth of twins throughout nation; significant rise in use of fertility treatments has largely contributed to 55 percent overall jump in births of twins since 1980; in NYC, since 1987, number of twins has grown 20 percent in city; problems of housing, finances, schooling and medical care associated with twins in New York City, discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Jonathan Alexander was sitting comfortably in his stroller, ready to roll. His twin sister, Rachel, was screaming. She did not want to wear a jacket. She did not want to take a walk. She did not want to do much of anything, it seemed, but arch her...

docs.lead_paragraph: Lest the title of tonight's PBS documentary, ''Jackie: Behind the Myth,'' leads you to fear you are in for two hours of digging the dirt, be reassured. This collection of encomiums couldn't be more respectable and less revealing if it was produced by a Jacqueline Kennedy fan club, which in a way it is. Relatives, friends and hangers-on in Camelot (Pierre Salinger, John Kenneth Galbraith and others) compete or conspire in affectionate reminiscences about their friend's life and accomplishments, such as they were. It begins on a poor-little-rich-girl note. Young Jackie loved to take care of her horses, but her parents quarreled and divorced, and she was shuttled between the Auchinclosses and the Bouviers. Happily, all were well off, and she recovered to become debutante of the year. There were also boarding school, Vassar, a junior year in Paris, a job (with the help of her stepfather) as the inquiring photographer on The Washington Times-Herald and marriage to ''Washington's most eligible bachelor.'' Eight hundred guests showed up for the wedding and 1,200 for the reception, but her father was kept away, and as the narrator says in a flight or descent into romance-magazine prose, ''No one could have guessed what the bride was enduring.''
docs.abstract: Walter Goodman reviews television program Jackie: Behind the Myth, on PBS; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Lest the title of tonight's PBS documentary, ''Jackie: Behind the Myth,'' leads you to fear you are in for two hours of digging the dirt, be reassured. This collection of encomiums couldn't be more respectable and less revealing if it was produced by...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bush Explains His Opposition to Abortion'' (news article, Nov. 22): One of the main reasons Gov. George W. Bush leads his likely Democratic rivals in the polls is that he enjoys significant support from centrist, pro-choice women. Many of these women are probably unaware of the extremism of Mr. Bush's views on abortion.
docs.abstract: Kyle Hudson letter Gov George W Bush is leading in polls because he enjoys significant support from centrist, pro-choice women, many of whom are unaware of extremism of his views on abortion (Nov 22 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the small world of women who are senior officers, Lois Beard was considered a prime candidate to become the Army's first General Mom. She was a veteran of the invasion of Panama and the war in the Persian Gulf. She commanded a military police battalion that helped keep the peace in Bosnia. The Army promoted her to colonel two years ahead of schedule.

headline.main: Motherhood Deters Women From Army's Highest Ranks

docs.abstract: Responsibility for raising children is keeping women from reaching highest ranks in US military; of all subjects that preoccupy those rising through ranks, few are more pressing than how to balance motherhood with all-consuming commitment required to become general or admiral; many who leave service put time away from family as overriding concern; men are evenly divided between complaints about pay, job security, possibilities of advancement and enjoyment of work; 37 women are currently active-duty generals or admirals; photo (M)
